title: Movie review; Performances, script crackle in powerhouse ‘Steve Jobs’
text:
Aaron Sorkin’s script, Danny Boyle’s direction and several towering performances light up the tech genius’ biopic Michael Fassbender fires up the intensity as the co-founder of Apple in “Steve Jobs.” (Photo: Universal Pictures) 
CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Steve Jobs was a complicated guy, a tech genius and towering visionary with the people skills of a fried motherboard.
In the explosive “Steve Jobs,” a powerhouse acting showcase with a firecracker script by Aaron Sorkin, Jobs (a titanic Michael Fassbender) hits on the heart of this dichotomy during a confrontation with Steve Wozniak (Seth Rogen, graduating to fine dramatic work).
“Your products are better than you are, brother,” Wozniak tells Jobs, and Jobs — not missing a beat — fires back, “that’s the idea, brother.”
It’s a rare moment of self-awareness from Jobs, who wore his prickliness like a coat of armor. “Steve Jobs” doesn’t ask you to love the guy, but it does paint a picture of who he was and how he dealt with others.
A decaffeinated Danny Boyle, breaking from his usual manic visual style, stages the film like a play, and it unfolds in three tentpoles in Jobs’ career: the Macintosh launch in 1984, the NeXT console debut in 1988 and the iMac unveiling in 1998.
“Jobs” boils down to a trio of fiery confrontations between Jobs and his child’s mother (Katherine Waterston), Apple CEO John Sculley (Jeff Daniels) and Rogen’s Wozniak. As Jobs’ “work wife” Joanna Hoffman, Kate Winslet is never far from his side as an oft-ignored voice of reason and compassion.
The three-act style allows the film to break from typical biopic conventions and allows Fassbender to up the intensity in a mighty role.
As Jobs, he’s an uncompromising force of nature, a worthy tribute to a man whose shockwaves continue to rock our world.

‘Steve Jobs’ 
GRADE: A- 
Rated R for language
Running time: 122 minutes
